newsitem.title: USA: Two weeks before Oscars - nominees act humble.
newsitem.headline: Two weeks before Oscars - nominees act humble.

text.p: Hollywood put on its humble face Tuesday as Oscar nominees expressed humility at being honoured for the movie industry's biggest awards.
At a luncheon for nominees before the March 24 Academy Awards ceremony, several stars expressed how being nominated was honour enough and winning an Oscar was not important.
But a few, like Kristin Scott Thomas, who is up for best actress for "The English Patient", were refreshingly honest.
"I'd love to win," she told reporters at the Beverly Hilton. "I feel like a child of six and I'm over the moon."

And Barbara Hershey, nominated for a best supporting actress Oscar for "Portrait of a Lady," was equally frank. "Honestly, I'd love to win," she said. "I am shocked at how much being nominated means."
Scott Thomas summed up the uncharacteristic humility in Tinseltown at this time of the year. The English actress said she had been at a photo shoot the day before with her son.
When she asked him what he thought of it, his reply was close to describing the feeling in Oscar-crazed Hollywood.
"'Mommy, everyone has to say they love you and that you look beautiful,'" Scott Thomas said with a wry grin.
Also at the luncheon was one of her rivals for best actress -- Frances McDormand -- who was nominated for her role as a small-town police officer in "Fargo".
"This is all pretty overwhelming," she said. "I lead a pretty simple life in New York."
After the Oscar ballyhoo has died down, McDormand said she was anxious to return to the stage. "I haven't done a play for three and a half years and I can't be away so long.
"It's a different set of muscles (from acting in films) and mine are atrophying," she said.
Billy Bob Thornton, who has been nominated for best actor and best adapted screenplay for "Sling Blade", brought a touch of good ol' boy earthiness to the glittering event.
"I feel like the ugly guy who got a date for the prom," he said in his southern drawl.

Asked by reporters if he would be wearing the same black T-shirt, jeans and John Deere baseball cap to the Academy Awards show, he laughed: "They won't let me. I asked but they said 'Show a little class.'"
Three nominees for best supporting actor were on hand -- James Woods for "Ghosts of Mississippi", Armin Mueller-Stahl for "Shine" and Cuba Gooding Jr., for "Jerry Maguire".
"All corny stuff aside, all the people in my category are friends or people I admire, so being nominated is good," said Woods, who plays a racist killer in the film.
He said he felt he had more chance this time compared to 10 years ago "When I was nominated (for best actor in "Salvador") against Paul Newman on his eighth try.
"It was like going to the guillotine then, and all we could do was practice our smiles."
German actor Mueller-Stahl said tongue-in-cheek: "I am proud and every day I get a little bit more famous."
Gooding, who played a football player represented by sports agent Tom Cruise, was asked how it felt to have one of his lines "Show me the money!" turn into a catch-phrase.
"It's sort of cool. When people get it, it validates you for your next character and I sure have validation now!"
His life had changed so drastically, he said, "now people ask how I pronounce my first name!"
